c_title: How Writing to Deadlines Can Hold Your Life Together
h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects on the surprising benefits of having to write a Lingua Franca post every week for seven years.

c_title: How Google’s Autotype Contradicts Orwell’s Advice
h_desc: To Geoff Pullum’s amusement
i_page: Gmail now offers phrases that are exactly the opposite of what the author of Nineteen Eighty-Four said writers should use.

c_title: The Web Page That Cannot Exist
h_desc: A tiny error on a conference web page provides Geoff Pullum with a concrete example for teaching abstract concepts in philosophy.

c_title: A Pocket Brexicon for American Academics
h_desc: Academics visiting Britain from the United States this holiday season will have trouble understanding some new words in the newspapers. Geoff Pullum has prepared a helpful Brexit glossary.

c_title: Blasphemy and the Strange World of Linguistic Crimes
h_desc: The medieval crime of saying things that outrage the pious exists in the 21st century
column10: making a “safe space” for religion written into the law in some lands.

c_title: A Moment of Sympathy for the Old Fogeys and Snoots
h_desc: In the matter of “can not” vs. “cannot
i_page: ” Geoff Pullum detects a flicker of fellow-feeling for the judgmental prescriptive usage pontificators of the world.

h_desc: Geoff Pullum was asked to write a book about his field for a lay audience and publisher. Two favorable referee reports left him feeling alone and deprived of counsel
i_page: so he resorted to the judgment of that harshest but most biased of referees

c_title: Sir Harold Evans Sneers at a Book He Has Not Read
h_desc: Why would a man modify a book on good writing by adding a misguided slur and a misattributed quotation? Geoff Pullum wonders

d_dateUK: Buried Long Ago in the Book Review Columns
h_desc: charles f. hockett
i_page: Geoff Pullum recalls a prescient observation about the relations between language and psychology
column10: lost seven decades ago in a place so obscure you would never have found it.

c_title: What’s in a Name? A Government Loses a National Referendum Over an Adjective
h_desc: A referendum to add “North” to a country’s name failed after its president called the renaming “historical suicide.” Geoff Pullum explains why that’s ridiculous.

c_title: What’s the Fastest-Growing Language in the U.S.? You’ll Never Guess
h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects on its rapid spread
i_page: the significance of its language family to linguists

h_desc: dolphin
i_page: Geoff Pullum is optimistic about linguistics’ application for practical matters. So why do news outlets perpetuate crazy talk about translating animal language?

d_dateUK: Dead Hand of John Dryden Still Perpetuates Grammar Myths
h_desc: john dryden
i_page: The fiction about not ending sentences with a preposition can be traced back to the whims of one influential 17th-century writer
column10: says Geoff Pullum. And that’s not all.

h_desc: merriam-webster
i_page: Is it “a number of X are” or “a number of X is”? It depends. Geoff Pullum discovers that Merriam-Webster’s Concise Dictionary of English Usage will not help you decide.

c_title: The Perennial Difficulty of Defining What ‘Descriptive’ Means in Grammar
h_desc: Geoff Pullum is locked in an intractable dispute with a colleague about whether so-called descriptive work on English grammar is in fact prescriptivism in sheep’s clothing.

c_title: Chinese Among High-School Seniors (and in the Movies)
h_desc: Mandarin is overtaking German among college-bound high-school seniors. Geoff Pullum reflects on what that might mean
i_page: and what the job prospects are.

c_title: Learning Useless English Grammar in Japan
h_desc: A teacher of English sends Geoff Pullum some puzzling exam questions on an arcane corner of grammar. Japanese students are not just drilled on such sentences
column10: but examined on them in crucial university admission tests.

c_title: Avoiding ‘False Titles’: How Some News Publications Try Not to Sound Like News Publications
h_desc: Geoff Pullum enlists Lane Greene of The Economist to explain why the magazine insists on using explanatory phrases

c_title: The Grammar of the Adjective Is Not What’s Wrong With ‘Illegal Alien’
h_desc: The Justice Department’s order that undocumented people should be called illegal aliens smacks of Newspeak but is linguistically unobjectionable. What’s nasty is the attitude behind it.

c_title: What’s an Anti-Semite? It Depends on Which Politician You Ask
h_desc: Can lexicography help solve political disputes about who is or isn’t anti-Semitic? Geoff Pullum doesn’t think so.

c_title: Writing on Philosophy: It’s Not Rocket Science. It’s More Complicated Than That.
h_desc: Geoff Pullum tackles a perfectly formed yet extraordinarily complex and demanding sentence from a recent text. Can he wrestle it into simpler form?

c_title: Friendly Communication Across Supposed Language Barriers
h_desc: A conversation in a neighborhood shop reminds Geoff Pullum that despite the hostility between India and Pakistan
i_page: spoken Hindi and Urdu are almost identical.

c_title: The Triumph and Tragedy of Oscar Wilde
h_desc: A London performance of An Ideal Husband prompts Geoff Pullum to reflect on all that has changed
i_page: 120 years too late for the playwright

d_dateUK: but the Myth of Her Linguistic Skills Lives On
h_desc: koko
column10: the famous gorilla did not master sign language
column13: notably in situation-bound efforts to get food from her trainer.

c_title: Strunk at 100: A Centennial Not to Celebrate
h_desc: Geoff Pullum argues that professors should stop sending students to a thoroughly outdated writing guide — and cites some alternatives.

c_title: Another Conquest by the Language That Is Eating the World
h_desc: In the Netherlands
i_page: colleges are expanding their enrollments by offering courses in English

c_title: Infinitives Can Be Split: Grammar Conservatives Face the Shock
h_desc: Geoff Pullum examines the reaction in the letters column to a recent surprising announcement by The Economist. Could Lingua Franca have helped strengthen the magazine’s resolve?

c_title: Amazon’s Alexa: Not Yet as Smart as a 5-Year-Old Child
h_desc: Geoff Pullum says natural-language processing is not ready for prime time

c_title: The Israel/Palestine Dispute Is Ill-Served by Uninformed Grammar Nitpicking
h_desc: Ethno-geopolitical affairs in the Middle East are complex
i_page: says Geoff Pullum. We do neither side any favors by discussing the tragic maelstrom of hostilities through ignorant quibbles about language.

d_dateUK: Google Duplex? No Artificially Intelligent Calls
h_desc: http://chronicle-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com/d0/57/2b0a68d664d61b406bf90d934170/screen-shot-2018-05-11-at-2-37-52-pm-copy.jpg
column11: examining a new development in artificial intelligence
column12: decides that he’s inclined to continue making his own phone calls.

f_image: 000 Years of Snobbery in the Suffix ‘-Monger’
column11: Geoff Pullum detects more than a hint of millennia-old bias in words like warmonger.

e_dateISO: and Windrush: the Naming of Political Scandals
h_desc: http://chronicle-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com/18/a2/4f825b40a4780e0b31b73e252f6b/windrush.jpg
column10: Geoff Pullum tracks some of the word-formation processes involved in the coining of names for new media firestorms.

c_title: Emoji Are Ruining Grasp of English
d_dateUK: Says Dumbest Language Story of the Week
h_desc: emoji
column10: says Geoff Pullum. Dropping the occasional pictograph into their prose is not going to strip people of the capacity to form sentences.

c_title: Can You Explain What a Shibboleth Is?
h_desc: Hearing BBC Radio use the word incorrectly
i_page: Geoff Pullum examines its Hebrew etymology and ancient history.

c_title: Copy Editing and Proofreading a Book: It Takes a Village
h_desc: Geoff Pullum tackles the editing and proofing of a short book on why linguistics matters
i_page: and is glad he wasn’t trying to do it alone.

c_title: The Problem with the Ban on ‘There Are’ Constructions
h_desc: Geoff Pullum wonders why usage advisers are so determined to get us to stop writing “there is” and “there are.” Some existentials (as clauses with those expressions are called) can’t be gracefully rephrased.
Geoff Pullum analyzes the subtle semantic underpinning of Cynthia Nixon’s amusing “unqualified lesbian” quip.

c_title: The Adverb That Killed a Friendship
h_desc: Geoff Pullum watched as a monosyllabic
i_page: unstressed adverb terminated a neighborly relationship.

c_title: Taleb on Pinker: Neologism and Bile
h_desc: Having browsed the latest books by each of these two noted public intellectuals
Geoff Pullum argues that spam invitations to junk journals and concocted conferences are not just annoying; they do actual harm.
